channel.title: Brisbane s calendar Museum of Brisbane

item.title: Light Fantastic: Expo
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 10am – 5pm



For some there are two Brisbanes – the one before World Expo ‘88 and the one that emerged after. The enduring legacy of Expo ‘88 was not what the world saw of Brisbane, but what we saw of ourselves.

To celebrate the 25th anniversary of this landmark event, Light Fantastic: Expo ‘88 Parades Rewired will take visitors back in time to rediscover the magic of the Lunchtime and the Qantas Light Fantastic Parades that mesmerised crowds every day.

Unlike anything ever seen in Australia before, creating the parades was an intensive process. The resulting joy for thousands of visitors only hints at the enormous energy and collaboration needed to bring the ideas to life.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Panoramas
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 10am – 5pm



Among the countless images taken since the introduction of photography to Australia in the 1860s, panoramas contain something special. Beyond the landscape, the photographs give an insight into life at different times in our city’s history when roads were rudimentary, horses gave way to early vehicles, and City Hall once towered over all.

Providing a fascinating insight into life in Brisbane over a 150 year span, the exhibition tracks Brisbane’s growth from a modest town nestled in the river’s curves to the modern city we know today.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: The River: A history of Brisbane
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 10am – 5pm



As the defining symbol of our city, the wayward and beautiful Brisbane River had bought us opportunity, sanctuary and at times heartbreak.

The River: A History of Brisbane explores our ever-changing relationship with the river. From its importance to the land’s traditional owners, to its discovery that decided our capital’s location, and the industry that was born on its shores, the river has played a critical role in the growth of our city.

Connecting you to the stories of the city, the exhibition charts a compelling journey from Brisbane's earliest settlement through to the modern city we call home.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Panoramas
item.description:
Tuesday, June 11, 2013, 10am – 5pm



Among the countless images taken since the introduction of photography to Australia in the 1860s, panoramas contain something special. Beyond the landscape, the photographs give an insight into life at different times in our city’s history when roads were rudimentary, horses gave way to early vehicles, and City Hall once towered over all.

Providing a fascinating insight into life in Brisbane over a 150 year span, the exhibition tracks Brisbane’s growth from a modest town nestled in the river’s curves to the modern city we know today.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: The River: A history of Brisbane
item.description:
Tuesday, June 11, 2013, 10am – 5pm



As the defining symbol of our city, the wayward and beautiful Brisbane River had bought us opportunity, sanctuary and at times heartbreak.

The River: A History of Brisbane explores our ever-changing relationship with the river. From its importance to the land’s traditional owners, to its discovery that decided our capital’s location, and the industry that was born on its shores, the river has played a critical role in the growth of our city.

Connecting you to the stories of the city, the exhibition charts a compelling journey from Brisbane's earliest settlement through to the modern city we call home.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

Beyond the landscape, the photographs give an insight into life at different times in our city’s history when roads were rudimentary, horses gave way to early vehicles, and City Hall once towered over all.

Providing a fascinating insight into life in Brisbane over a 150 year span, the exhibition tracks Brisbane’s growth from a modest town nestled in the river’s curves to the modern city we know today.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: The River: A history of Brisbane
item.description:
Tuesday, June 18, 2013, 10am – 5pm



As the defining symbol of our city, the wayward and beautiful Brisbane River had bought us opportunity, sanctuary and at times heartbreak.

The River: A History of Brisbane explores our ever-changing relationship with the river. From its importance to the land’s traditional owners, to its discovery that decided our capital’s location, and the industry that was born on its shores, the river has played a critical role in the growth of our city.

Connecting you to the stories of the city, the exhibition charts a compelling journey from Brisbane's earliest settlement through to the modern city we call home.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Light Fantastic: Expo
item.description:
Wednesday, June 19, 2013, 10am – 5pm



For some there are two Brisbanes – the one before World Expo ‘88 and the one that emerged after. The enduring legacy of Expo ‘88 was not what the world saw of Brisbane, but what we saw of ourselves.

To celebrate the 25th anniversary of this landmark event, Light Fantastic: Expo ‘88 Parades Rewired will take visitors back in time to rediscover the magic of the Lunchtime and the Qantas Light Fantastic Parades that mesmerised crowds every day.

Unlike anything ever seen in Australia before, creating the parades was an intensive process. The resulting joy for thousands of visitors only hints at the enormous energy and collaboration needed to bring the ideas to life.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: The River: A history of Brisbane
item.description:
Tuesday, June 25, 2013, 10am – 5pm



As the defining symbol of our city, the wayward and beautiful Brisbane River had bought us opportunity, sanctuary and at times heartbreak.

The River: A History of Brisbane explores our ever-changing relationship with the river. From its importance to the land’s traditional owners, to its discovery that decided our capital’s location, and the industry that was born on its shores, the river has played a critical role in the growth of our city.

Connecting you to the stories of the city, the exhibition charts a compelling journey from Brisbane's earliest settlement through to the modern city we call home.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Light Fantastic: Expo
item.description:
Wednesday, June 26, 2013, 10am – 5pm



For some there are two Brisbanes – the one before World Expo ‘88 and the one that emerged after. The enduring legacy of Expo ‘88 was not what the world saw of Brisbane, but what we saw of ourselves.

To celebrate the 25th anniversary of this landmark event, Light Fantastic: Expo ‘88 Parades Rewired will take visitors back in time to rediscover the magic of the Lunchtime and the Qantas Light Fantastic Parades that mesmerised crowds every day.

Unlike anything ever seen in Australia before, creating the parades was an intensive process. The resulting joy for thousands of visitors only hints at the enormous energy and collaboration needed to bring the ideas to life.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

Connecting you to the stories of the city, the exhibition charts a compelling journey from Brisbane's earliest settlement through to the modern city we call home.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Light Fantastic: Expo
item.description:
Wednesday, July 3, 2013, 10am – 5pm



For some there are two Brisbanes – the one before World Expo ‘88 and the one that emerged after. The enduring legacy of Expo ‘88 was not what the world saw of Brisbane, but what we saw of ourselves.

To celebrate the 25th anniversary of this landmark event, Light Fantastic: Expo ‘88 Parades Rewired will take visitors back in time to rediscover the magic of the Lunchtime and the Qantas Light Fantastic Parades that mesmerised crowds every day.

Unlike anything ever seen in Australia before, creating the parades was an intensive process. The resulting joy for thousands of visitors only hints at the enormous energy and collaboration needed to bring the ideas to life.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Panoramas
item.description:
Wednesday, July 3, 2013, 10am – 5pm



Among the countless images taken since the introduction of photography to Australia in the 1860s, panoramas contain something special. Beyond the landscape, the photographs give an insight into life at different times in our city’s history when roads were rudimentary, horses gave way to early vehicles, and City Hall once towered over all.

Providing a fascinating insight into life in Brisbane over a 150 year span, the exhibition tracks Brisbane’s growth from a modest town nestled in the river’s curves to the modern city we know today.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000
